items.title: Walking just 4,000 daily steps once a week cuts risk of early death in older people, study suggests
items.standfirst: Researchers say the target significantly reduces risk of dying and lowers likelihood of cardiovascular diseaseOlder people who only walk 4,000 daily steps once a week still reduce their risk of dying early by a quarter, a study suggests.Staying active is known to bring a wide range of health benefits. But many people in their 60s, 70s and beyond may struggle for a variety of reasons to maintain the step count they used to reach. Until now it has been unclear how much people need to do as they age to reap the rewards. Continue reading...

clusters.title: The ultimate meaning of ‘six-sevvuhnn!’ and everything | Brief letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Slang and the meaning of "six-sevvuhnn" discussed

items.title: The ultimate meaning of ‘six-sevvuhnn!’ and everything | Brief letters
items.standfirst: A hitchhiker’s guide to slang | Wassup | Royal formerly known as Prince | Trump tactics | Men practising pilates | Lowering blood pressureI trust that the young people saying “six-seven” (Pass notes, 20 October) realise that the product of those two numbers is 42, which, according to Douglas Adams’ The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy, is “the Answer to the Ultimate Question of Life, the Universe and Everything”. It’s what we old people say.Toby WoodPeterborough• My 13-year-old granddaughter, Sophia, confirms that randomly yelling “Six-sevvuhnn!” is trending at her school. This sort of thing is nothing new: when her mother was at school, the fashionable standard greeting between teenage boys was “Whassup?”.Mark NewburyFarndale, Yorkshire Continue reading...
items.content: A hitchhiker’s guide to slang | Wassup | Royal formerly known as Prince | Trump tactics | Men practising pilates | Lowering blood pressureI trust that the young people saying “six-seven” (Pass notes, 20 October) realise that the product of those two numbers is 42, which, according to Douglas Adams’ The Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy, is “the Answer to the Ultimate Question of Life, the Universe and Everything”. It’s what we old people say.Toby WoodPeterborough• My 13-year-old granddaughter, Sophia, confirms that randomly yelling “Six-sevvuhnn!” is trending at her school. This sort of thing is nothing new: when her mother was at school, the fashionable standard greeting between teenage boys was “Whassup?”.Mark NewburyFarndale, Yorkshire Continue reading...

ai_summary: A letter discusses the meaning of "six-sevvuhnn" in slang.
The author notes the product of six and seven is forty-two.
The author references Douglas Adams' "Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy".
A granddaughter confirms the phrase is trending at her school.
The letter compares the phrase to the slang "Whassup" from the past.

clusters.title: ‘An unsolved mystery of science’: why do I dream about my teeth falling out?
clusters.neutral_headline: Dreams about teeth falling out explored by experts

items.title: ‘An unsolved mystery of science’: why do I dream about my teeth falling out?
items.standfirst: Experts say such dreams of dental distress may relate to the processing of various emotions and experiencesMy teeth have fallen out at fancy dinners and in public restrooms. They’ve sprinkled from my mouth like enamel confetti before dates, important business meetings and major public speaking engagements. Each time, it’s troubling, stressful and deeply inconvenient. Fortunately, it’s only ever happened in my dreams.“A lot of people have that dream,” says Dr Dylan Selterman, associate teaching professor in the department of psychological and brain sciences at Johns Hopkins University. People often tell Selterman they think it’s weird that they have this kind of dream, or assume it says something about their personality. “I don’t think that’s the case,” he says. Continue reading...
items.content: Experts say such dreams of dental distress may relate to the processing of various emotions and experiencesMy teeth have fallen out at fancy dinners and in public restrooms. They’ve sprinkled from my mouth like enamel confetti before dates, important business meetings and major public speaking engagements. Each time, it’s troubling, stressful and deeply inconvenient. Fortunately, it’s only ever happened in my dreams.“A lot of people have that dream,” says Dr Dylan Selterman, associate teaching professor in the department of psychological and brain sciences at Johns Hopkins University. People often tell Selterman they think it’s weird that they have this kind of dream, or assume it says something about their personality. “I don’t think that’s the case,” he says. Continue reading...

Such dreams may relate to processing various emotions and experiences.
People often find the dream troubling, stressful, and inconvenient.
An expert says it is not necessarily indicative of personality traits.
The dream is a common experience for many individuals.

clusters.title: ‘Chasing the ideal gut’: Poop-tracking cameras claim to give health insights. Are they necessary?
clusters.neutral_headline: Poop-tracking cameras claim to give health insights

items.title: ‘Chasing the ideal gut’: Poop-tracking cameras claim to give health insights. Are they necessary?
items.standfirst: Products like Dekoda can run up to $600 and photograph your every bowel movement – but who owns that data?You can buy a smart ring to track your sleep activity or a smartwatch to monitor your heartbeat, so perhaps it makes sense that health tech’s next frontier has come for your toilet. Behold: Dekoda, Kohler’s new toilet cam. No, not that type of toilet cam: this one only shoots pictures down at what is inside the bowl, sending the snaps to an app that analyzes stool samples and rates your gut health. The Dekoda can be yours for $599, plus an annual subscription fee.Kohler’s new product joins Throne, a $319 offering from an Austin-based startup. “Throne captures stool and hydration patterns, hands-free and automatically,” the camera’s description reads. “Notice shifts sooner, fine-tune daily choices, and feel more confident, every day.” Continue reading...
items.content: Products like Dekoda can run up to $600 and photograph your every bowel movement – but who owns that data?You can buy a smart ring to track your sleep activity or a smartwatch to monitor your heartbeat, so perhaps it makes sense that health tech’s next frontier has come for your toilet. Behold: Dekoda, Kohler’s new toilet cam. No, not that type of toilet cam: this one only shoots pictures down at what is inside the bowl, sending the snaps to an app that analyzes stool samples and rates your gut health. The Dekoda can be yours for $599, plus an annual subscription fee.Kohler’s new product joins Throne, a $319 offering from an Austin-based startup. “Throne captures stool and hydration patterns, hands-free and automatically,” the camera’s description reads. “Notice shifts sooner, fine-tune daily choices, and feel more confident, every day.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: Products like Dekoda photograph bowel movements for health insights.
Dekoda can cost up to $600, raising questions about data ownership.
The product analyzes stool samples and rates gut health via an app.
Another product, Throne, offers similar features for $319.
These devices aim to provide insights into gut health through analysis.

clusters.title: A day in the life of caring for an overdose survivor
clusters.neutral_headline: A day in the life of caring for an overdose survivor

items.title: A day in the life of caring for an overdose survivor
items.standfirst: John-Bryan ‘JB’ Jarrett lives with devastating brain injuries after overdosing on fentanyl. Despite the uncertainty of his prognosis, his mom, Jessica, is by his side 24/7The hidden victims of the opioid crisis: the ones who livedA couple of years ago, I began investigating non-fatal overdoses.Coverage of the US’s opioid crisis has largely focused on lives lost. But through my cousin Mason, I saw another toll of the epidemic: the people who survive overdoses but are left with devastating disabilities. Continue reading...
items.content: John-Bryan ‘JB’ Jarrett lives with devastating brain injuries after overdosing on fentanyl. Despite the uncertainty of his prognosis, his mom, Jessica, is by his side 24/7The hidden victims of the opioid crisis: the ones who livedA couple of years ago, I began investigating non-fatal overdoses.Coverage of the US’s opioid crisis has largely focused on lives lost. But through my cousin Mason, I saw another toll of the epidemic: the people who survive overdoses but are left with devastating disabilities. Continue reading...

items.title: The hidden victims of the opioid crisis: the ones who lived
items.standfirst: After overdoses left them with brain injuries and lasting complications, Americans are struggling to get proper care. Experts call it another epidemicA day in the life of caring for an overdose survivorJohn-Bryan “JB” Jarrett was supposed to be fishing on the Saturday morning of Labor Day weekend, September 2020. Over dinner the night before, he told his mom, Jessica, he wanted to be on the water by 7am.Jessica and JB were unusually close. When her work brought her to Austin, she stayed in his spare room; when the pandemic hit, she moved in for good. Despite a full life – a girlfriend, a job, a side hustle running an online thrift store – he welcomed her. They planted vegetables, packed meals for homeless people, watched true crime, even shared their phone locations. Continue reading...
items.content: After overdoses left them with brain injuries and lasting complications, Americans are struggling to get proper care. Experts call it another epidemicA day in the life of caring for an overdose survivorJohn-Bryan “JB” Jarrett was supposed to be fishing on the Saturday morning of Labor Day weekend, September 2020. Over dinner the night before, he told his mom, Jessica, he wanted to be on the water by 7am.Jessica and JB were unusually close. When her work brought her to Austin, she stayed in his spare room; when the pandemic hit, she moved in for good. Despite a full life – a girlfriend, a job, a side hustle running an online thrift store – he welcomed her. They planted vegetables, packed meals for homeless people, watched true crime, even shared their phone locations. Continue reading...

The article explores the long-term effects of the opioid crisis.
The focus is on the survivors of overdoses and their struggles.
The article highlights the hidden victims of the opioid crisis.

clusters.title: Beef, pork, chicken: the world loves cheap meat. If people knew what really goes in it, that love affair would be over | Devi Sridhar
clusters.neutral_headline: Cheap meat and antibiotic use discussed by expert

items.title: Beef, pork, chicken: the world loves cheap meat. If people knew what really goes in it, that love affair would be over | Devi Sridhar
items.standfirst: Antibiotic use in farming is now rampant and you should care about that. How meat is produced in China may mean the drugs you need here won’t workWhat we’re putting into our bodies can either nourish us, or make us ill. With that in mind, I wrote recently about the role of food consumption in terms of the risk of colon cancer. But what about food production?Across the world, we are seeing the rise of cheap meat: largely driven by demand from a rising middle class who finally can afford beef, pork and chicken, which used to be out of reach, given their cost. Approximately 45% of global consumption growth is occurring in upper-middle-income countries including China, India, Brazil, Indonesia and the Philippines. Poultry is set to take an increasingly large share of that growth (projected to grow by 21% by 2034), because it is relatively cheap, widely acceptable and requires fewer resources per kilogram compared with beef or pork. By 2034, it is estimated that poultry will provide 45% of the protein consumed from all meat sources.Prof Devi Sridhar is chair of global public health at the University of Edinburgh Continue reading...
items.content: Antibiotic use in farming is now rampant and you should care about that. How meat is produced in China may mean the drugs you need here won’t workWhat we’re putting into our bodies can either nourish us, or make us ill. With that in mind, I wrote recently about the role of food consumption in terms of the risk of colon cancer. But what about food production?Across the world, we are seeing the rise of cheap meat: largely driven by demand from a rising middle class who finally can afford beef, pork and chicken, which used to be out of reach, given their cost. Approximately 45% of global consumption growth is occurring in upper-middle-income countries including China, India, Brazil, Indonesia and the Philippines. Poultry is set to take an increasingly large share of that growth (projected to grow by 21% by 2034), because it is relatively cheap, widely acceptable and requires fewer resources per kilogram compared with beef or pork. By 2034, it is estimated that poultry will provide 45% of the protein consumed from all meat sources.Prof Devi Sridhar is chair of global public health at the University of Edinburgh Continue reading...

ai_summary: The world's love for cheap meat is driving antibiotic use in farming.
Antibiotic use in farming is now rampant, according to the author.
The author discusses the impact of food production on health.
Poultry is expected to take a larger share of meat consumption.
The author is a chair of global public health at the University of Edinburgh.

clusters.title: Three cases of severe mpox reported in California, health officials say
clusters.neutral_headline: California Reports First US Spread of Severe Mpox Strain

items.title: Three cases of severe mpox reported in California, health officials say
items.standfirst: Unrelated cases mark first time clade I of disease formerly known as monkeypox has spread within US, officials sayThree California residents have been infected with clade I mpox, a more severe strain of the virus formerly known as monkeypox – marking the first time this type of mpox has spread within the US, health officials said on Friday.The unrelated cases, identified in Long Beach and Los Angeles county, involve patients who had not recently traveled abroad. All three were hospitalized and are now recovering, according to the California department of public health. Continue reading...
items.content: Unrelated cases mark first time clade I of disease formerly known as monkeypox has spread within US, officials sayThree California residents have been infected with clade I mpox, a more severe strain of the virus formerly known as monkeypox – marking the first time this type of mpox has spread within the US, health officials said on Friday.The unrelated cases, identified in Long Beach and Los Angeles county, involve patients who had not recently traveled abroad. All three were hospitalized and are now recovering, according to the California department of public health. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Three California residents contracted clade I mpox, a more severe strain of the virus.
These unrelated cases mark the first US spread of this specific mpox type.
The patients, in Long Beach and Los Angeles County, had not traveled recently.
All three individuals were hospitalized but are now reportedly recovering.
The California Department of Public Health provided the information on Friday.
